citation.article-title: Vibrio species associated with mortality of sharks held in captivity.

p.s: Description of Vibrio carchariae sp. nov.
(kaf-kar-i. Gr. masc. n. carcharias "shark" or "critter with rough teeth")
Vibrio 1116b (ATCC 35084) is a gram-negative bacillus, but characteristically is more pleomorphic and frequently forms longer rods than 1116a.
It has an average cell size of 1.6 x 0.5 μm.
The cells are usually surrounded by a conspicuous capsule which is, in turn, encompassed by an amorphous slime.
Mixed flagellation is a feature of 1116b (Table 1). Vibrio 1116b also forms large central inclusions of PHB, and tends to occur as pairs of cells clustering in the slime (Table 1).
Biochemical characteristics of Vibrio 1116b are listed in Table 2.

Notable traits for this isolate are oxidase positive; sensitive to 150 μg of 0/129; decarboxylation of lysine and ornithine; reduction of nitrate to a nongaseous product more reduced than nitrite; production of indole; rapid (< 12 hours) hydrolysis of urea, gelatin, and chitin; acid produced from sucrose and salicin; and growth in 8%, but not 10%, NaCl.
The percent G + C (Tm) values for Vibrio 1116a and 1116b were 42.4% (SE = 0.5) and 46.3% (SE = 0.8), respectively (Table 2).
The mean values were calculated from analyses of 6 different DNA preparations obtained from each organism.
G + C values for the DNA standard, Escherichia coli ATCC 11775, averaged 50.5% (SE = 0.9).
A percent G + C value was also calculated for V. damsela CDC-2588-80, and was found to be 42.1% (SE = 0.6).
